citation.article-title: Two new species of Microbispora from Indian soils: Microbispora karnatakensis sp. nov. and Microbispora indica sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Microbispora indica sp. nov.

Morphology. Substrate and aerial mycelia are formed. The aerial mycelium forms a main hyphae and branches. Spores are formed in pairs on the branches of aerial mycelium. Spores are round to oval, measuring 1.2 to 1.6 Î¼m in diameter. Basal spore is attached to mycelium with a short stalk. Spore surface is smooth. Mycelium does not fragment into coccoid or bacillary structures.
Aerial mycelium is pinkish-white on oatmeal agar and light gray on glycerol glucose agar, yeastmalt extract agar, and glycerol agar with yeast extract.
The reverse color is violetorange on oatmeal and glycerol glucose agar and deep yellowish-brown on glycerol asparagine agar with yeast extract, potato-dextrose agar, and yeast-malt extract agar.
Starch is not hydrolyzed, gelatin is not liquefied, and milk is peptonized.
Carbon sources such as D-(+)-glucose, L-(+)-arabinose, and L-(+)- rhamnose are utilized for growth, but not glycerol and mesoinositol.
Cell wall composition. mesoDiaminopimelic acid, madurose, and galactose are present.
The type strain is SKF-I-101055 (ATCC 35926), isolated from soil, Tamil Nadu State, India.
